remixed_from.author: theodroid
remixed_from.title: Adjustable/Rotating Mount for Raspberry Pi Camera V2

title: Pi cam cover with square hole

description.text:
This is a remixed cover design for the Pi Camera Mount designed by theodroid. I put an 8mm square hole in the center (a little larger for actual part dimension and tolerance) to accomodate my ArdCAM module (SKU:B0033). Although the placement of the pin/hole board and shell mounts are correct, I wasn't having luck with them as far as holding the assembly together. The pins are fragile on my prints and keep breaking off too. I did an additional remix to allow the case front/back to be held together with fasteners.

Special thanks again to theodroid for the original design:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1718628

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20 layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used supports everywhere in Cura. The 'remix' is only for the front case cover, or the fastener-assembled version of the cam case. I used the theodroid's original stl/designs for the arm and mount components.

Cleanup

After printing the rear shell, remove the supports from the slot very carefully before taking out the main body supports. Be careful not to tear off the thinner edge of the cable slot when removing the rear case support materials.

After removal of support and general cleanup, I fastened my build together using M3 (6mm long) cap screws and nuts.

This was re-mixed by importing the stl files to DesignSpark. After importing an object for modding:
1) Select the entire object
2) Right-click the selected object

On the popup menu click Convert to Solid. I used 'merge faces' on the submenu.

description.text:
For the upcoming Halloween festivities. I took the model http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:172348
and used it as a starting point for a human head sculpt.
It was necessary to cut the bottom flat in meshmixer and export to .obj
so I could rework it in sculptris.
but a nice starting point

I used 5% infill to ensure the top was supported
had a few cracks
filled in with ABS/acetone goop
vapor polished I personally don't like infill on big peices
seems like i get worse cracks than holes
(well it really depends on the model)
but for these head sculpts i think it is better to clean
up post printing.
anyhow,,,,
with 5% infill this is a hefty 125.2 grams
@ $0.032
it comes to $4.01

title: Two-voice Double Ocarina
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: A two-voice double ocarina consistent of two individual ocarina's tuned a perfect 5th apart. They can be played separately or together by blowing in both holes simultaneously. Each one is designed that a full octave can be played with only one hand. The fingering is straightforward. Start opening the holes from bottom to top then to the thumb. For the double holes, first open the one in the middle of the instrument followed by the outer one.

comments.text: Hi, thanks for this model it's really cool and sounds great compared to other ocarina's I have printed (no tuning) and I've had fun trying to work tunes out on it :)

author: Caran

title: High Tech Chopsticks with ring to hold them together.

description.text:
Running out of ideas for things to design I saw some titanium chopsticks similar to these (not exactly the same) and I decided to make my own design. I each sushi a lot so they will come in handy.  
While designing them I decided they would fit together with bottoms facing each other so I also created a ring you slide on them to hold them together for easy storage and carrying.
I printed with a .35mm nozzle at .15mm layer height. No support needed. Rotate the sticks 45 degrees if you have a 200mm print bed. I printed with a brim since my first attempt lifted.

author: tmorris9

remixed_from.author: Mak-a-face
remixed_from.title: i3 Adjustable Y Belt Holder for GT2 & T2.5

title: Original Prusa i3 MK2 Adjustable Y Belt Holder

description.text: This was remixed from i3 Adjustable Y Belt Holder for GT2 & T2.5. The base was made thicker and the belt holder was shifted farther away from the end so that the holder can hit the Y endstop without running into the motor. The belt holder assembly was also made shorter front-to-back to fit within the standard Prusa i3 MK2 configurations, so it doesn't hit the motor at one end and the belt holder at the other. When mounting, the adjustment screw should point towards the front of the printer.

author: Wolfie

title: 12mm LED cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I needed to paint a display prop after assembling the pixels so that their body and the wires would all get painted black. I didn't desire to put blue painter tape on all 200+ pixels so I designed this cap.

I can print about 120 of them in a couple hours and I have a nice reusable cap for painting.

author: Wolfie

title: Customizable i3 Glass Bed Corner Bracket

description.text:
I had my glass cut to the largest size my printer would hold and the biggest PEI sheet I could get. So my print area isn't exactly a standard dimension. I developed a bracket I could customize to make it fit. Good measurements and a little trial and error provided the the perfect sized bracket for my glass.

This bracket does not hold the glass down. It keeps the glass from moving in the x and y direction.

Customize this in OpenScad (free). Export to STL. Slice in your favorite slicer (Slic3r). Send g-code to printer.

description.text:
Lost one of the clips on the kickplate, and was never able to get it properly seated. Why not print a replacement?? Only took a few minutes in 'quick and dodgy' print mode!

This is an alternative to Electrolux part no 0125008358. May suit AEG, Westinghouse, Chef, Simpson, Kelvinator, Dishlex freestanding fridges and ovens. If it looks like this it's probably the right one!

Please note that no guarantees are provided regarding the use of this part or its suitability in a particular application.

Solidoodle 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30% recommended

Notes:

Two versions of STL file - one has modelled supports, the other doesn't.

  • If you print the one without supports, you will need to arrange some for the unsupported features.
  • If you use the one with supports, I recommend a raft or brim to help the supports stick to the bed - will be messy if they come adrift.

Print plenty of walls, so the clip part is entirely made up of walls (1.0mm / 2x wall/shell setting minimum). Infill should be reasonably strong, it's a small part. Mine worked well at 30%.

Cleanup

Cut off the support and any raft/brim and plug it in.

Insert into the oven at 90 degrees, and twist until the locating spigot fits into the corresponding hole in the oven frame.

The square tab and locating spigot should be at the top.

The kickplate should be inserted by the top first, with holes fitting over the square tabs. Then the bottom is pressed over the bottom clips, and should click into place.
Measurement of existing part, modelled in CAD software.

description.text:
This Thing is a modified version of jsirgado's caster, with wheels of my own design, to fit my Broyhill model 41119 office chair (well, that's the model number used by "True Innovations", the supplier; it's actually a "Wal*Mart fall-apart special" :P ).

To be specific, I shrunk down the axle "hump" so that the caster fits the chair's ~50 x 5.7 mm wheel axle, and ~7mm diameter caster pivot (that's the lower part, 10.9 mm in the upper part). Grab a hammer, you'll need to pound pretty smartly to get the pivot and axle into their respective holes in the caster and wheels. :-) You may also need to pass a drill bit through the caster's axle hole to clean it up (easily done by hand).

The wheel is closely based on the chair's original wheels.

Use supports for both; beware of supports being inserted into the bottom of the caster pivot hole.

title: Flashforge Creator Pro Super Duper Spool Hanger

description.text:
Edit: Sep-19-2016: changed the design to metric.

This is a super duper hanger for the Flashforge Creator Pro and similar printers. This design has a few advantage

  • Bearings based, virtually zero friction.
  • Easy to mount and remove the spool. No screwing required.
  • Easy to install and remove holder from the printer (e.g. in tight places)
  • Fits all common spool form factor and spool holes, including Hatchbox spool with 1" hole.

Printing: print in the orientation of the provided STL file. This orientation will provide the max strength. I printed with ABS, 4 bottom/side/top layers, 0.2mm layers with 0.4mm nozzle, 20% infill and support material from the printing bed to that large round bump.

Materials: M6*90 screw (e.g. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0143ACXD4), 4 X 626 bearings (I prefer the plastic/glass type, search ebay for '626 Plastic Nylon POM Ball Bearings', they turn smoothly, open don't require lubrication, don't rust, and light weight), and an M6 hex nut.

Assembly: debar the spacers and other holes (use a debarring tool such as Shaviv or a large drill bit) insert the bolt into the base, inserts the spacers and bearings insert the end piece and the nut and tighten everything.

Verifying your assembly:

  • Make sure that all the bearings turn freely. The spacers are designed with chamfer at their ends to make sure the touch only the center part of the bearings.
  • Make sure the end piece is well tighten and that it is pointing up. If it doesn't point up, release it, release, turn the bolt in the base a third of a turn or so and tighten again.

Printer:

Flash Forge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Make sure to print in the orientation of the provided STL. This will provide the best strength and filament fibers orientation. The big oval bump require support, the rest doesn't. Make sure not to have support at the bottom of the spacers to have cleaner interfaces with the bearings.

title: Pac-Man
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Pac-Man fans will appreciate this small (32mm diameter body) one piece fun print that features a mouth that opens wide / closes tight shut and everything in between... just like Pac-Man. Two .stl's have been provided. One is a 'just for fun' model. The other includes a key fob fitting (In the most practical place for reliable printing).

A larger more practical version of this design is my Pac-Man Containers which is available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1754407. In this file the mouth parts are internally moving drawers to store small things like mints / sweets etc.

This should be an easy PLA print for anyone with a good slicing app and accurate machine with a filament fan. This is important due to the fine detail and clearances as well as the extreme angles applied... when printed well they work great and are fun little things that amaze people.

The design must be printed face down (as per he .stl's provided) to keep the internal parts separated from the outer structure. Adequate clearances have been applied to work for most machines so the mouth should be free to move straight off the build plate (... once the raft is removed).

Please do not use any automated support. This will permanently fuse the parts together. This print does not require any support but Raft with 4 - 5mm outset if required to ensure good build plate adhesion through the minimal contact areas.

If the parts stick and won't move post-printing a gentle amount of pressure is all that should be required to free them to move. You may also need to check there is not excess filament in the mouth area causing the parts to fuse together slightly.

3D prints with moving parts often don't move smoothly because the surfaces that come in contact with each other are slightly rough / imperfect. If you want to make the mouth parts in this print rotate smoothly and fast a quick spray with some silicone spray is your solution (Refer images).

Please refer to the print settings / instructions and images for additional information. These Have been test printed numerous times on Makerbot Replicator 2's and 5th Gen. MakerBot's with consistently great results (as shown in he photos). .

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.... and post images of your Pac-Man prints!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

2 shells / 20% or more infill.

Notes:

Prints well in PLA on machines with a filament fan. This is necessary due to the extreme angles used.

Do not use any automated support. This will fuse the internal moving parts.

Remove the raft, free up the mouth parts and have fun with your Pac-Man!

On a well set up machine and with a good slicing app the mouth parts should free up easily post-printing, Just gently push on the tabs and/or internal mouth parts to start the rotation.

If not, chances are it will be a fraction of excess filament around the mouth area. Clean it away and your mouth parts should be free to moves.

If the mouth parts do not move smoothly (due to the internal 3D printed surface texture) a light spray with some silicone lubricant can get them moving with next to no friction.

Some of the details on the rings may be too thin to print. After I have a chance to print them I may change the designs a bit. Background artist here http://www.deviantart.com/art/RWBY-Emblems-Insignias-406733674.

author: zealtv

description.text:
Recently my old timer Jeep lost the rubbers that go between the shock absorber and the mounting pin. These parts are hard to come by and our local dealers want to sell the complete shock only. So I printed them very successfully with semi flexible TPE filament. The specific filament I used had a hardness of 45D. This filament will not work on all extruders. Bowden becomes very tricky. I made a modified part for the standard bowden extruders found on many cheap delta printers. This modification allows flexible filament to be printed using a bowden extruder. Printing speed is very slow. 1cm/s can be reached; however, I tend to print at 5mm/s which gives the most reliable results. It also allows the rubber to melt into the previous layer giving a much more solid and technically sound part. The semi flexible rubber TPE works well on a heated bed on 50'C with masking tape, and on the masking tape a thin spread out layer of contact glue (the yellow sticky stuff you use to glue carpets or shoes "Pattax Tix Gel").

Assembly: Press the rubber through the shock. It will compress and fill the gaps once you bolt it into place. The sequence should be first a big washer, then the rubber into the shock, thenn press the shock over both mounting pins, then another large washer, and then lock in place with the nut.
you can write 3 times words at one stroke!

description.text: Made a Mobius mount for the GEP-210 quad frame. The idea with this was to give it a tilt angle as well as keep it narrow in order to be able to use 5 inch props.

Printer:

Wanhao 4S

author: FpvLeo

title: Semi flexible TPE bowden extruder modification

description.text:
Printing with TPE on a bowden is said to be impossible. Not anymore: The modification to the compact bowden extruder allows the rubber filament to be forced into the feeding hole without allowing it to twist out of the feed. The filament I used was hardnes 45D and is called semi flexible TPE rubber 1,7mm thickness.

After printing the part you need to drill the feeding hole open with a 1,5mm or 2mm dril. This hole where the filament is feeded into needs to be smooth and must be perfectly aligned with the pulley.

Maximum printing speed is +-2cm/s although if the extruder is dirty or old you will reach the most reliable result at 5mm/s. Its not fast but it works. Temperature of filament =240'C. Make sure the bowden tube has no sharp kinks or bends. The trick is to smooth the path to the head as much as possible.

Make sure you are not feeding faster than what is needed. Measure the actual feed length for a 100mm feed and adjust the speed accordingly. Rubber parts will need to be printed solid. I found that printing with a infill density of 95%, is solid enough and allows for excess feed to find a spot to settle.

IMPORTANT: flexible filament can not retract. The retraction needs to be switched off.

Let me know if you had success or if you are struggling and you need help.

comments.text: Works great with an MK8 drive gear. I'm able to print ninja flex with this setup.

title: Kossel Mini Cross Brace
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mount designed to hold cross bracing rod for a Kossel Mini delta printer (https://github.com/jcrocholl/kossel). The default parameters are for a 15mm x 15mm OpenBeam frame which uses M3 hardware and an M5 threaded rod, but could easily be changed to another frame size and mounting hardware.

The Kossel design is triangular and prone to vibration because the upper frame can twist compared to the base. These cross braces provide diagonal support along the upright rectangles, removing the ability for it two twist.

Hardware required to use this design per side of the Kossel:

  • Threaded rod of a length determined by the SCAD file (approximately 650mm for Kossel Mini)
  • 4x M3 nut (to mount to frame)
  • 4x M3 bolt (to mount to frame)
  • 2x M5 nut (to tighten the rod on the diagonal)

author: LR74

description.text: Slider-style linear potentiometer. The resistive element was printed using conductive ABS filament. This design isn't perfect as the values still fluctuate a little bit when adjusting the slider, but usable and a LOT better than my previous designs. Also sub-optimal is that I'm only reliably able to get about 4 bits of resolution out of it. It's tricky to print useful potentiometers out of currently available conductive ABS filament because of the very high resistance (think megaohms) and the fluctuation in resistance with pressure and bending. The orientation that you print the resistive element matters a lot. Increasing surface area seems to help as do springs to stabilize the pressure. Here's a video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TaeihVHN1Wo

comments.text: Do you think the low resolution problem can be solved if a higher conductivity filament is used? The graphene 3D and Functionalize offer graphene- and carbon nanotube-filled PLA filaments. The volume resistivity of both filaments are around 1 ohm cm, which is at least 15 times lower than Protopasta. How conductive do you want the filaments to be?
comments.author: CuFan

comments.text:
Have you considered using mini bearings as the contacts?
Other thoughts:
You may be able to exploit the change in resistance when it flexes.
clocksping style element may give you a rotary style, and increase the resolution.
*Try a wedge or arrowhead design to increase resolution, and print flat (z rotate 90 deg)
comments.author: Dranoweb

comments.text: Also if the resistance of the printed sheet of conductive material changes in a semi predictable way with regard to applied pressure the "problem" could be used as a sensor.
comments.author: talpa

comments.text: Very true. The way the resistance changes with bending and pressure does lend itself to different types of sensors. It tied a simple flex sensor, and it works, but the resolution that you can reliably measure is very low due to the extremely high resistance. There's just so much noise! I'll post a couple of the things I've tried.
comments.author: talpa

comments.text:
If the noise is "white" sampling multiple times and averaging might help.
Assuming that you doesn’t already do this
comments.author: jijimath

comments.text: All good ideas. Most of them tried/incorporated already. Need to see if shielding helps though. Good suggestion. Thanks!
comments.author: talpa

comments.text:
Have you considered using the core of a regular pencil those have a way lower resistance, and you are already using semi exotic vitamins like copper tape.
While it probably defies the assumed challenge of printing the resistive element it would give you a nice low Ohm resistor.
comments.author: talpa

comments.text: I liked this idea so I took some measurements.  The standard (hardness H) 0.5mm mechanical pencil lead I tested had a resistance of about 0.055 ohms per mm.  In other words, I think you'd have the exact opposite problem.  Even if you took two leads and set it up so the wiper bridged between them you'd have a max resistance of around 6 ohms which I'm worried would be pretty touchy in operation. :(
comments.author: talpa

comments.text: A pencil... cool idea! But yes, the idea here was to print as much of the potentiometer as possible. I was originally trying to print the wiper and terminals too, but the resistance is just way too high, hence the copper tape. As these materials improve, better designs will open up.

title: Minimal Dashcam Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My dashcam came with a suction mount and after it falling one too many times, I decided to make this. The design was somewhat inspired by the one shown (which I tried but didn't work in my application).

The gap between halves is quite large but I was annoyed that the other mounts I printed didn't hold tight enough without sanding them way down.

This design is crude but fits all of my requirements: works, small, holds the dashcam steady, doesn't fall.

I used this mount to attach a dashcam to my rear window with 3M double sided foam tape. And yes, I absolutely colored it with a Sharpie.

After testing different shapes and angles I have finally reached the sweet spot on both. The gap below the surface is so the Vg bends to the profile of the Rc planes wing. After installation, I recommend closing the gap with tape and epoxy(or just tape) so the high-pressure air does not escape through it cancelling out the vortex. Glue it on using epoxy or superglue. I don't recommend sticky tape because it will raise the VG a lot and it will look bad. Not intended for full-scale aircraft. Place each VG at least 4 cm apart (or you will effectively be creating an airbrake). if you put this on your plane please upload a pic. The line marked as 10˚ on the VG should be parallel to the line(imaginary) that runs through the centre of your plane. There is an image that relates to this. You can also see a picture of my final wind tunnel simulation I ran using Autodesk Flow Design

title: New aluminium extruder for 3D printers by PiBot.com

description.text:
PiBot.com releases new Spring loaded extruder for 3D printers. The new metal extruder offers a significantly higher torque with compact design. All metal parts are anodized with comfortable texture. Extruder reliability is increased and its filament could be processed with high speed.  
This design incorporates a spring-loaded arm to squeeze the filament between the drive gear and a bearing with a constant amount of pressure. Minimizing the chance of skips due to variance in filament thickness.A simple spring height adjustment part is included to easily increase the spring rate if needed. With this piece, you will avoid loosening and tightening the screws of the extruder every time you change your printer filament .One-Handed Operation makes inserting new plastic filament to the extruder easier.  
The mounting support is designed for hot ends with a diameter of 6mm and could be assembled on most 3D printers. Due to its compact design, it is also suitable to be mounted as a dual extruder.  
you can see more in reprap.org it is opernsource or pibot.com

author: barnr

title: Modifications to QU-BD extruder for reliable ABS printing.

description.text:
I had been having trouble printing ABS using the QU-BD extruder on my Hadron Ordbot. The extruder runs fine for small models and but when I would do prints of larger models with long print runs, I would consistently get a feed failures after a couple of hours of printing. I tracked this down to hot section heat slowly creaping up the stainless steel feed tube causing melting outside of the hot section melt chamber.   Research showed that this was not uncommon for QU-BD styles print heads because the top of the feed tube cannot stay cool enough when printing ABS.  See How I did it below.  
Enjoy

I had a local machinest make a new new feed tubes with a high temperature PTFE (Teflon) tube from McMaster Carr. This acts as filiment insulation for the feed tube of the qu-bd heater block. This design is derived from Matt Donley's work.  Attached are my pdf drawings of what I sent and got back from my machinest friend.  
After running the modified head well over a 100 hours, I dismantled it and found that there was no melted filiment anywhere except in the melt chamber where it belongs.  
I now happily print ABS reliably for any size part running for any amount of time. As an FYI, I print ABS at 235C.  I run my bed at 110C for the first layer and 100C there after. The bed is glass covered with Clear Monokote and the Monokote is sprayed with thin even coating of AquaNet Super Hold hair spray.  I have NO PROBLEM with stick down and parts come off of the print bed absolutely clean.  Better yet the Monokote surface only has to be remvoed and replaced every 30 or 40 prints and the hairspray surface every 4-6 prints.

I wanted to make a sphere in a cube.

v1: simple wireframe cube containing a sphere with diameter equal to the cube side lentgh.
v2: rather use a diamond shape for the sides so the top frame is supported
v3: use a diamond shape for all sides, since it is easy enough to bridge (especially if you print up to 50% scale)
v4: add manual suports for the top frame and the spere.

I've had success printing up to 50% scale, 0.4 layer height, PLA and about 40% infill (to avoid the sides of the sphere to curl up on the bottom).
Fix it with a pice Powestrip!

title: Hex Screw Clamp with Gear output

description.text:
I've seen these motors on sciplus for years now, and just recently saw them on amazon. Since their popularity means other people might be using them, here is a model that makes mine much more useful. Included is a picture of the kind of motor I designed this for.
Instead of using the outer edges of the threads as a shaft, or paying almost a thousand dollars for a tap set for 7/16 ACME threads, clamp these to either side of the screw shaft and drive something with 40mm hex.
Needs 6 m4 nuts and 6 30mm m4 screws. New version includes provision for an M3 setscrew(optional). will require two m3 nuts and two m3 setscrews.
There is a gear on the shaft for driving a rotary encoder. Also included a gear for the encoder.
For the curious, I use this to drive gears like the big one included in this thing.

title: Z Brace Yourself - Alternate Straight Braces for Wanhao i3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An alternate set of Z Braces to improve the rigidity of the printer. Compatible with the Wanhao i3 (aka Cocoon Create, Mono select). Made from scratch, based on the principles of Typhons https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1359774 and Azzas excellent https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948.

These braces are designed to have straight rods for aesthetic reasons, with the rods positioned as close together as possible to maintain rigidity. Typhon's Top Braces impede into the build area of the printer which decreased the usable Z height by 20mm. These braces regain that space by moving the rod mount to above the bottom inner screw. These brackets also clip around the front and back of the base to improve rigidity.

Build Of materials

  • 8x 3/8" Hex Nuts
  • 2x 3/8" Threaded rods cut to 365-375mm
  • 20x M3 x 15 mm screws
  • Optional Anti Vibration Pad. https://www.bunnings.com.au/whites-100mm-x-1m-anti-vibration-pad_p3961983 (Significantly Reduces Vibration and lowers sound levels)

Update June 2017

Added a number of additional parts to increase the rigidity of the printer.

  • Optional Tower feet (Increases lateral stability)
  • Optional Front brace (with zip tie gap to brace Y-pulley)
  • Optional Rear brace (Reduces Flex)
  • M10 Metric Editions of the existing parts by popular request.

New photos are attached which show the new parts and also the rubber vibration pad used to isolate the printer from the ground.

Tinkercad source link: https://tinkercad.com/things/9eYjIPDR2y8

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Cocoon Create

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.22

Infill:

50+

Notes:

PLA recommended at 45%+ infill.
Supports not required 4 outlines plus recommended.

Guide

Install the top mounts first with 4x M3 screws each. Do not completely unscrew all 4 screws at once to prevent the frame from shifting. The Inner Bottom screw is hidden behind the area where the nut is held.

Install the Bottom Rear left and right brackets with 3x M3 screws each.

Screw the threaded rod into the top mounts and lock it in with 2 nuts on each side.

On the end of each rod, screw in a nut - front bracket - nut. Attach the the front bracket to the frame. Use a square against the vertical frame to ensure the printer remains 90 degrees square to the ground. Screw the rods in back and forth as needed till the vertical frame is perfectly level.

Optional.

Cut the dampening pad into the shapes of the bottom brackets and glue them to the base with gel or superglue. The pad decouples the printer with the ground which reduces vibrations and makes the printer much quieter.

Bought some nuts and the threaded rod. I notice it was really hard to get the nut in place.

comments.author: Varazir

comments.text: There isn't any need to turn the nut in the top part, simply put the nut in the gap in the top frame and screw the threaded rod in from below. The bottom nut in the bottom section should have enough room so you can screw it in or out slightly as needed. You may take a few tries to make sure the frame is 100% straight with the tower exactly 90 degrees to the ground. Once these are lined up tighten up the two other nuts and you should have a square and sturdy frame. Screws don't have to be 100% exact, there is a a few mm leeway in length each way.

comments.text:
Hi,
I tried to print the walls last night. The back wall does not seem to print all of the lumber sections. Specifically, the right hand piece of the 'T' prints but the left hand piece and the upright do not print. I noticed in my print preview, the right hand piece is highlighted in blue while the left hand bits are not. Any ideas? A friend suggested that the mesh on the model might be broken/disconnected.
John
comments.author: jacar

comments.text:
Hi,
Thanks for the feedback. My slicer reported the cross beam as an error but having had a look I think the upright beam may have had a gapping issue. It seemed strangely reluctant to fix, so I re-made the rear wall and have re-posted it. I also noticed a gap behind the door which may cause printing issues, so amended that one as well. So both ends have been replaced. (Can't say I'm surprised as this was one of my very (very) early builds, and it probably needs re-visiting)
Thanks for pointing it out
Cheers
Earsling
comments.author: jacar

comments.text: The back piece printed fine.  BTW, the front piece also printed fine.  I did not have an issue with it the first print run through.  The roofs are on the printer now.

description.text:
This is V2.

The K40 laser is a good machine that needs alot of mods to work well.

With this bracket you can mount the PSU of the machine 90 degree tilted, so it will use the air in the room to cool the PSU, rather than using the heated are inside the laser for cooling.

Theese brackets are made for PSU with width of 144mm and height of 79mm.
If you have another size, send a comment and i will add your PSU type too!

Please note, the electronics in theese machines are sometimes bad, for your protection, add a extra ground wire from the casing of the PSU to the casing of the laser, as it is now isolated from the chassis. As a extra precaution.

2 versions included.
1x 6mm thick, and 1x 4mm thick.
Choose the one you want, i would suggest the 4mm.
If you move your laser alot, use the thicker one.

Update: Holepatterns for the PSU uploaded. Please check your PSU before printing.
I´m happy to get comments if your holepattern is different and add more variations.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

description.text: I needed more hooks in my room and had plenty of doors in my room. So instead of having to drill holes in my walls I came up with this.

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

No

Yes

0.1

20%

Notes:

To print it strong you don't want to print it laying flat, so I tried to have the layers diagonal through the shape, but this makes it considerably harder to print.
I recommend rotating it on it's side, then laying it flat and then rotating it up again 60 degrees.
I've rotated it over the Z axis so that the support lines align with the shape of the hook.
See pictures from after the print.
To dissipate the heat, when printing only one, I added a "cooldown tower".

When you need to print your own horn for servo motors, the 3D printers produce slightly different results so that the horn may not fit to the servo.  
With this tester a bar is printed which has holes with a radius of 2.7, 2.8, 2.9, 3, 3.1, 3.2 and 3.3 millimeters.  
So print the tester out, attach it to your servo and find out the radius you need for your horns.

This is a collection of parts that I put together to allow the easy addition of extra lead screw towers onto V-Rail extrusion framed CoreXY printers. The goal: perfect bed movement stability.

Hardware (items first, a few amazon links after to make it easy):

The bottom bracket and stepper dummy require an M5x50 Sockethead bolt to serve as the shaft, each of these should have a GT2 Pully attached underneath a Flex coupling.
Each are attached to the V-Rail extrusions via M5x10 Socketheads into M5 Square nuts.

The bottom bracket spacer is attached using four M3x25 Socketheads and the internals require a series of 5x10x4 mm bearings (one on top, and three on the bottom).

The belt tensioner requires a GT2 idler pulley set in place with a M3x25 Sockethead into a M3 nylock nut.
The tensioner arm is held into place atop the spacer using 2 M5x10 Socketheads, one from the top, the other from the bottom.
The tensioner base should be attached to the V-Rail with M5x10 socketheads using M5 washers to prevent deformation; furthermore, the assembly should be anchored using M5 square nuts just like the parts above.

The top bracket requires the same anchoring hardware to the V-Rail along with four M3x10 Socketheads anchored into the leadscrew fitting.

NOTE: The top and bottom brackets are the same part.

Links:

400mm 8mm Lead Screw - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B017AR5QBS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Flexible Couplings 5mm to 8mm - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B016KFRR0O/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
5x10x4 mm Miniature Deep Groove Ball Bearing - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00ZHSTKCE/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
GT2 Timing Belt Pulley 16 Teeth Bore 5mm Width 6mm - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B019GI5DVC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: Raspberry Pi Zero Enclosure with audio amp option

description.text:
This is yet another remix from an original design by egil, an enclosure for a Raspberry Pi Zero. The design is in OpenSCAD and is fully parametized. The two scad files listed here are in fact the same file with different options set. The same file can be used to print enclosures for a standard Raspberry Pi Version 2/3 simply by changing the option "pi_zero = 0" in the scad file.

The scad file also allows for fitting various add on boards, and terminals/openings in the enclosure. An example is shown here where an add on PAM8403 audio amplifier card is included attached to the Pi Zero with an i2c DAC card from pimoroni.com. The PAM8403 is an incredibly cheap and small audio amp with quite acceptable performance IMO.
For my project I used software from the Rune Audio project which does not officially support Pi Zero, but a user has provided a software image which works great. See
http://www.runeaudio.com/forum/raspberry-pi-zero-support-in-0-4-t3711-40.html

description.text:
The idea was to create a waterwheel, which is driven by a water pump und additional lifts water into a second circulation to feed a waterwork (plateaus).

The waterlevel must be almost under the wheel so the three buckets can fill themselves with water.

Additionally you have to use aluminum strives for the frame and a PVC hose for the pump.
In the top item i have drilled 3 whole to the back and to the sides into the aluminium and the hose, but not in the direction of the wheel so the water can smoothly leave to start element.

The wheel is fixed on a 8mm threaded rod, which is hold with 2 bearings in the frame.

I have created this thing with 123Design, you can download the complete construction in one 123Design File to adapt it at your wishes.

Here the wheel in its first real life: https://youtu.be/_AevDTsDgLg

Wanhao 5s mini

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes:

I am happy with my Wanhao 5s mini, because it has a giant pressure bed.
But the wheel is so big, that the wheel must be printed with 2 halfes.

The prints are huge and need a lot of filaments, so think on every part, how many infill is needed at this position!
I have used all my rests of filament, you can see that at pans :-)

description.text:
This thing use 2 parts :

This one for the base layer and numbers and the second one put a colored background for readability.

This way you end up with a complete street number in 2 colors.

You can generate both layers for street numbers between 1 and 99999.

Printer:

Zortrax m200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.19

Infill:

medium

Notes:

I use PLA with Z-TEMP because both layers are really big and flat surface..

Profile: Z-ABS
Z-TEMP offset between -50° and -60° Heat bed switch to 0.

Some UHU stick help a lot to keep the print in place.

Both layers must be pushed one again the other, no need to glue but the upper layer may need some sanding to allow the base number to fit..

Remember that PLA is fragile and that applying to much power in to push will break the parts.

Hope this helps.

title: 25 mm Fan support for M3D Head (to cool the extruder motor)

description.text:
The M3D printer has several conception issues. One of them is that the extruder motor is not enough cooled. As a result, the extruder motor stops running during prints, giving lots of failures for large prints (higher than 10 mm ...). As some guys on the forum explained, a fan can be attached to the head using some tape: it works but its not "clean" and time proof: that's why I designed this part (you'll find the FreeCAD source files, or you may just download the STL file).
This support allows you to add a 25mm fan in order to cool down the extruder. This way, you will be allowed to print things with this printer (wow !). You can use the same fan than the M3D one, or buy a cheaper one on ebay (25 mm x 25 mm x 7 mm or taller). Then you can bolt it to this part with M3 bolts. Please note that the clips that keep this part fixed on the printer head require to remove the front cover, but please free to use the FreeCAD schema and enhance it if you which !
You may print it with as few options as possible (no draft, ... just use a support), in "low" or "medium" quality, with the smallest infill possible (as the part is quite thin).
You can power the fan as I did: using a spare usb cable (will give 5v).
PS: I'm french and my english may have some mistakes, if you find some mistakes, please be free to notice me ;)

title: Case for SB400 Solderable PC BreadBoard

description.text: i was building an IoT device (internet of things) using a Amica (Nodemcu v2) and needed to do the final assembly so I used an SB400 prototyping board. The case will neatly fit an SB400 plus female headers plus micro controler on it plus about 3mm gap vertically. horizontal gap is less than a mm. I've successfully printed this and am using it now. It's designed to the opening is at the bottom so that any moisture can go out the bottom. The end cap fits snug. Suggestion if you are using simplify3d change Y has to 90 degrees and then use Edit/center and arrange feature. Then you are ready to go.

description.text:
This is a Xiaomi Yi 4K mount that is designed to fit a specific underwater housing and is intended to mount on the 2 center lines of a kite used for kitesurfing or similar activity. Check out the video I added for an example of the type of footage you might get using this mount.

The specific housing I used this on is a clone "Newmowa Waterproof Case for Xiaoyi YI Sport Camera II 2 Xiaomi Yi 4K Action Camera (White )" and is currently available here:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01I4XME0S
I believe it will work non-clone version but I have not tested this.

Space is provided for a foam floaty and I typically use a small piece of line to tether the whole setup to the lines but I've tested this pretty well as seen at the end of the video. I also make soft line grips that go in the fingers by squeezing RTV out of a tube cut to the right diameter.

author: kb20607

title: Quad 33 control amplifier disc adaptor cover for use with phono plugs

description.text:
The Quad 33 control amplifier (preamp) was designed in the 1960s, but it's not out-dated. It still does precisely what a stereo preamplifier should do. However, the phono preamp part of the amplifier is a bit limited in that it is suitable only for moving magnet cartridges.

For me, though, the biggest problem is that due to the arrangement of my hifi, my record player is several metres from the Quad 33. This means extra long cables, more capacitance and dulled treble as a result. I therefore want to use my extrenal phono preamp near to the record player and run most robust line level signals into the Quad.

Quad published a sheet of information in the 1990s which covered how to adapt the phono preamp to accept line level inputs, but this kept all the circuitry in use even though it made it close to a unity buffer. There's no need to do that. I've removed the Quad preamplifier from the circuit altogether as its simply not necessary when a line level input is required.

See this webpage for more details: http://www.hembrow.eu/personal/quad33-303.html#phonomod

author: davidhembrow

description.text: This is a modified version of the Battery holder. This version has no posts to hold the strike plate. But it still holds a battery, DPS magnet & security wrench to pull the cover off with.

This hunter style pocket watch features a watch body, cover, chain, and clip. It prints fully assembled without any support! Check out a video of it in action:
http://youtu.be/wPkB516yhzQ We've included two files in this upload: PocketWatchFinal is specific to our watch module (Check out the "Instructions" tab for more info). PocketWatch_Oriented is a more generic watch case, and is intended to be a base to build off of.

Do not print with support material! PocketWatch_Oriented can be loaded into Makerware and printed straight away. If you are having trouble getting the chainlinks to stick, try using a raft. PocketWatchFinal is designed to be used with the watch module found in this paper watch on Amazon. The first half of the watch is printed, then the print is paused, and the watch module is inserted. The print then resumes, enclosing the module within the pocketwatch. The print can be paused at around 7mm; this should be high enough to clear the watch module, but low enough that the printer won't start bridging the gap. Note: We found that the heated build plate on the Replicator 1 was a bit too much for our little watch module, and it overheated to the point of failure. Keep this in mind if you have a Rep1 or a 2X!

author: yaronlilach

title: 1996 Pontiac Bonneville Complement Light (Door Light) Housing

description.text:
I created this piece after the one that I have in my current Bonneville broke. Each door has a light in it; this is the housing for said lights. This file may need a little bit of tweeking yet, but for the most part, it is completely functional.
This is my first thing on this website. I have used Thingiverse for quite a while now and figured I would give back after I designed this.

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes
